title: Dance With Me!
name: Megan E. Bryant
review_text: Strawberry Shortcake for a new generation. Sigh.

title: All In (The Blackstone Affair, #2)
name: Raine Miller
review_text: This second installment of this series was nice. I liked that it was from Ethan's point of view and you get to see a lot more of his vulnerabilities. Looking forward to the final installment, but I do hope the author would consider Ivan and Gabby as a stand-alone series!

title: House of Mystery, Volume 7: Conception
name: Matthew Sturges
review_text: As with many of the other volumes, the core story here is pretty decompressed due to the substories within and the story ends right in the middle, but this is nonetheless an enjoyable continuation of the House's story that is clearly moving toward conclusion. The Annual at the end was only so-so.

title: Captain Marvel, Volume 1: In Pursuit of Flight
name: Kelly Sue DeConnick
review_text: Can I just get a comic about the Banshees? Not that Carol Danvers isn't great, but I would love to see more of them.

title: Twilight Phantasies (Wings in the Night, #1)
name: Maggie Shayne
review_text: This was pretty good. Your typical paranormal romance. Girl falls for vamp, they get their signals crossed more than once, etc. The storyline was a little different and the characters are really likeable. Definitely worth the read and I will be looking for more by Maggie Shayne.

title: Rapture (Fallen, #4)
name: Lauren Kate
review_text: Amazing end to the series. So happy that Daniel and Luce could finally be together! :)

title: Born Standing Up: A Comic's Life
name: Steve Martin
review_text: I had a hard time getting into this, but turned out to be entertaining. I'm glad I listened to this and I'm sorry I got my dad the actual book instead of audio for christmas. This is def a book to listen to as Steve Martin actually reads the book. It makes all the difference when you hear him do some of his comedy bits.

title: All In (The Blackstone Affair, #2)
name: Raine Miller
review_text: Wowowow... This book was so intense and emotional..... I just finished it and I am balling... The love and emotion just come off the page.... I don't know what else to say other than this is a fantastic work of art!!!!!!!!

title: Shifter: City of Wolves
name: Avery Burch
review_text: At 97% of book read Ihad to stop reading. Couldn't take it anymore  It began in a good way, but lots of topics and non sense bored me to no end. Good idea about the shifters purge, though. And very nice of the author to offer an ARC to me. Sadly, this book wasn't my cup of tea

title: Three Imaginary Boys
name: J.T. Holden
review_text: I really enjoyed this novel. It was a fun, easy read that I was throughly entertained with. For me, it was a quick read, but it didn't feel rushed or inconclusive. I loved the plot, it was really unique and unlike anything I've ever read, which is always amazing to find in a book. It's so hard to keep my full attention with certain books, but this book I didn't have a problem with that.  Drew and Logan are such interesting characters. Both so different, but alike in certain aspects. It was fun to see such different characters side by side. I really connected with some traits of both characters, which I enjoyed. All in all, it was a great book! I really recommend it to readers.  I received this book in exchange for my honest review.

title: Witches
name: Kathryn Meyer Griffith
review_text: WITCHES  Author: Kathryn Meyer Griffith  Type of Book: Audiobook - Unabridged  Narrator: Erica L. Risberg  Length: 10 hours, 50 minutes  Genre: Paranormal Fiction  Release Date: May 31, 2013  Rating: 3.5 out of 5 stars  * I received a free copy of this audiobook from the author in exchange for an honest review.  Two witches living in the same town several centuries apart.  It is the 1700s and Rachel Cox is the talk of the town. They say she is a witch and they whisper whenever she walks by. It is a terrifying time to be accused of witchcraft. Witch hunts and burning at the stake are common.  Amanda is a modern day white witch. She is grieving the loss of her husband Jake and is just starting to try to figure out how to live without him.  There has been talk locally about a satanic cult practicing in the area. When murders begin happening the residents of the small town are scared. And, as always, scared people act irrationally. They start looking for someone to blame and despite living there for ten years, they chose her as their target.  Amanda must decide whether to permanently leave the house she loves and abandon the townspeople to the evil in their midst or whether to stay and fight to protect the town despite their hatred towards her.  This is a story of good vs. evil, but is also a tale of prejudice and the fact that people tend to fear anything or anyone they do not understand.  The author does a terrific job of incorporating the supernatural into the modern world. She also weaves history with present day.  The narration of this book was not as good as I had hoped. Much of the delivery is in monotone and the different characters do not have distinct voices. The voice used for Rebecca's familiar (a mouse) was horrible and it was weirdly similar to the voice used for the character of Sebastian. However, there are stretches of time where the narration is very good. This is just a personal observation. I recommend listening to this book yourself and making up your own mind about the narration.  I rate this book as 3.5 out of 5 stars.  ABOUT THE AUTHOR:  Kathryn Meyer Griffith is the author of twenty-two published novels as well as novellas and short stories.  To learn more about her visit http://www.goodreads.com/author/show/...  To read more of my reviews visit http://amiesbookreviews.wordpress.com

title: My Mother's Secret
name: J.L. Witterick
review_text: A very short book about the Holocaust and living to tell about it. Excellent read.

title: The Girl on the Train
name: Paula Hawkins
review_text: While not as shocking as Gone Girl, I thought The Girl on the Train was messier, in a good way. No one was \cool\"
language: no one was a \"seductress.\" Everyone was messed up and that whole middle-class
n_votes: picket fence dream life played a big part.  Also
date_added: I Iistened to this as an audiobook and the decision to have different actresses voice the point of views was a smart one. Really added to the mystery!"

title: Crush
name: Carrie Mac
review_text: a very light, sweet intro to GLBT literature. It's so sweet and really shows the struggle of Hope as she tries to understand what it all means. and how nature it is and how sweet love is.  I will pass this on to my teen

title: The Fifth Favor
name: Shelby Reed
review_text: I LOVED this book. So much.

title: Cress (The Lunar Chronicles, #3)
name: Marissa Meyer
review_text: LOVED IT!! But I wish I would have waited to read it! Now I have to wait till 2015 till the next book comes out! Ugh!!! Loved the way that Scarlet, Cinder, & Cress's stories all intertwine so amazingly...really great series.

title: Stealing Rose (The Fowler Sisters, #2)
name: Monica  Murphy
review_text: WOW! The sexiest, most exciting, fascinating, captivating, compelling book I have read so far this year, and probably the best New Adult book I have ever read! It's a simple and very complicated story, with the best character development I have seen in ages, if not ever. Expect the unexpected. I'm in love with STEALING ROSE! Monica Murphy is a genius! Just read it!

title: The Way We're Working Isn't Working: The Four Forgotten Needs That Energize Great Performance
name: Tony Schwartz
review_text: AMAZING Book.  If you work in a corporation, you HAVE to read this book. It'll make you MUCH more efficient at work, and MUCH happier in life.  Tony Schwartz has been doing the \Energy Project\" research for over 10 years. He published 2 previous books. He consulted for top CEOs from around the world. And at the end of all that
language: he compiled this amazing book that brings Academic Research & Behavior Psychology in one hand
n_votes: and then very practical long-term tried practices from the offices of top Managers in the world.  Every chapter is a pleasure to read and is immensely useful. And when Tony doesn't feel the science is clear about something
date_added: he says that clearly. (e.g. the chapter about Nutrition
review_len_words: he started by saying it's a wasp's nest). No hand waving."

title: Her Rancher Bodyguard (Martin's Crossing #5)
name: Brenda Minton
review_text: This is an excellent book!!! I loved reading every minute of it.

title: Dancing with Mr. Darcy: Stories Inspired by Jane Austen and Chawton House
name: Sarah Waters
review_text: I wanted to love these stories, but I found myself skimming them and bored by them. Maybe just a case of wrong book at the wrong time.

title: Fatal Vision
name: Joe McGinniss
review_text: Engaging story about an \All-American\" man who is accused of killing his family. Set and written in the late 70s/early 80s. Shows its age in some ways
language: though the casual sexism of some of the characters does not go unanalyzed; in fact
n_votes: it contributes to a picture of the role misogyny played in the crimes and the investigation of them.  Some of the psychological analysis feels quaint -- and a little too lengthy -- but generally feels like a realistic of the long
date_added: drawn-out process of investigation and trial for murder
review_len_words: without (very often) feeling too slow. In spite of its length
column13: I genuinely wondered about the innocence of the main character til the end. Enjoyed the device early in the book of two parallel stories: the background and history from the point of view of the pro/antagonist leading up to the crime
column14: and the investigation after the fact."

title: Dreamfever (Fever, #4)
name: Karen Marie Moning
review_text: I love this series! This book goes beyond the other 3 because in the other three Mac was pink and thinking about her wardrobe and nails, she is now black and thinking about revenge and survival. Plus, after the last book ended with the 3 unseelie princes I honestly didn't think there would be a Mac. I liked Monings way of having Mac and Barrons \come\" together without really having it have to affect the relationship. Like her books before
language: I am dying to know what comes next. This one ends in a horrible fashion I am pretty sure I would prefer Mac \"being\" with the unseelie princes as long as Barrons can take care of her than facing what she faced in the end of this book-of course we aren't sure of the who
n_votes: but we know the what and the what is pretty bad!"

title: Rapture (Fallen, #4)
name: Lauren Kate
review_text: Not my favorite book of the series, but Rapture wraps the trilogy up nicely. I had a difficult time getting into the beginning, but enjoyed the end. I had guessed part of \the big reveal\" but there was still an important half to it that I did not see coming."

title: Cure For The Common Life
name: Max Lucado
review_text: Absolutely worth reading! See for yourself.

title: The Widower's Tale
name: Julia Glass
review_text: I am not sure how this book received such high marks -- it was bogged down by tons of expository text and unnecessary details. When I was only 11% of the way through, I felt like I should have been at 80%! I finally managed to read the whole thing, but it was cumbersome and dreary.

title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Harry Potter, #7)
name: J.K. Rowling
review_text: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is one of the best out of the series. It's a really great book and I think it's good for all ages.

title: Invincible Microbe: Tuberculosis and the Never-Ending Search for a Cure
name: Jim  Murphy
review_text: A history of tuberculosis told in shocking details and facts. Murphy's writing is perfection when it comes to the world of children's nonfiction. It is easy to comprehend and incorporates stories from real people who struggled with the illness which gives the information a human touch as opposed to straight research information that comes across as dry and unappealing to readers of all ages. Information is supported by numerous photos of good quality. I learned so much about this disease including the fact that the fight isn't over. Tuberculosis continues to evolve and doctors the world over work hard to develop treatments. Recommended for grades 6-8.

title: Cress (The Lunar Chronicles, #3)
name: Marissa Meyer
review_text: With Scarlet I'd initially disliked that new characters were being added while rarely going bak to old ones (ie I started mad core shipping Scarlet and Wolf instead of shipping Cinder and Kai because they took a whole other book to finally get a chance to be in the same room together again) but I really enjoyed meeting Cress and Thorne. An of course I ship them too now. I'm starting to feel like there's a theme happening here.  Regardless, good solid book, good solid characters, keen for the next one to come out. Wishing that Scarlet and Wolf could be united already because he is my bby and it breaks my heart to see him this way.

title: Tales of a Female Nomad: Living at Large in the World
name: Rita Golden Gelman
review_text: Some countries written on her travelogue :  Mexico, Guatemala, Nicaragua, Israel, Galapagos Islands, Indonesia ( Bali, Yogjakarta, Borneo, Irian Jaya-the easternmost Indonesia) United States, Canada, Thailand.  The minute I read one page of this book, I was hooked!- I wanted to go on and on- If life were only to read! I might not want to put this aside until the last page.Truth to be told, I was attracted to read this book as Indonesia, my country was told there.One of her sayings written on her travelogue I can recall is that people love it when they hear about their countries.. Her writing about Indonesia arouse my curiosity.  There are of course a few other reasons why I decided to pick this book ; the first reason was because I put a great passion for traveling, meeting new people, tasting different kind of cuisines, and feeling the culture shocks. I love traveling, only that I often don't have time to travel, and often I think of the limited budget. I have lived in Indonesia since I was born. Let's say I have had a job since I was 23. That means I could have bunches of opportunities to explore my own country- but I can't at least not yet. Having read her book,which I prefer calling it as a travelogue really moves me. Not only does it tell about cultures, but also it tells how beautiful friendship is, how small the world actually is.  Her travelogue to some countries mentioned above is indeed so great experiences to read and probably to encounter that I felt like being drawn into her journeys, feeling what she feels. At times, she is capable of making me laugh because of what she had experienced in her journeys. For sure, tears welled up in my eyes when I read some of the tragedy happened in her journeys.I am not sure what I would do, how I would feel if I were in her positions dealing with some shocking events all by myself- no one helps me. All of sudden, you become a very self-sufficient person, because you have to  I remember a proverb \ When you are in Rome

review_len_words: it is an ever lasting friendship you will get; your life will be rewarded by a bliss.  Long before I finished reading her book

title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Harry Potter, #7)
name: J.K. Rowling
review_text: I cried tremendously with this being the last book in the series knowing that my immersion in this magical world was coming to an end. There's not much more to say other than thank you to J.K. Rowling for sharing Harry with us.

title: The Girl on the Train
name: Paula Hawkins
review_text: I read this to see what the hubbub was about. This book has a huge waiting list at my library. I went in cold, no reviews and no idea what it was about. It's very readable. Great storytelling trance. I pounded it out in less than two days and found myself regretting that I couldn't get back to it. It's a thriller and I normally do not read thrillers, and there were some times I wanted to reach into the book and smack some of the characters. Some of it is believable when you read it, but then when you think about it later you'd be hard pressed to rationalize some of the actions of the main character.  Great beach read. Highly recommended for someone who wants to be absorbed by a story.

title: The House Between Tides
name: Sarah Maine
review_text: I kind of go a bit crazy when someone mentions a book with a crumbling old house, a desolate setting, secrets and a dual timeline. I love those kind of Gothic undertones through a book and as we're in the middle of winter, it's the perfect time to sit down under a blanket and devour it. I was really happy when I received this surprise book (yes, it doesn't take a lot to excite me) but external forces conspired against me to read this at the speed I wanted. The House Between Tides is a solid read and those who are fans of Kate Morton will particularly enjoy this tale set in the wilds of Scotland.  The story is told between two major timelines, that of Theo and Beatrice in the late 1880s and 1900s before shifting to Hetty in the present day. Theo marries Beatrice and they move to the rugged wilds of the Outer Hebrides for Theo to paint. It all sounds incredibly romantic until Beatrice starts to realise that Theo has some ideas that are rather...odd. Her new friendship with the Cameron family isn't that welcome. When Hetty arrives in the present day to the now overgrown, crumbling estate (can't you just picture it, all grey and spooky with a lone raven calling overhead?) she's introduced to the descendants of the family after being caught trying to break into her own inheritance. Very shortly after, she discovers there's a skeleton in one of the rooms, which kind of wrecks her plans to build a hotel on the island. But what's the mystery? Who is this mysterious person and what secrets of the past does it hide?  I must admit that I guessed the mystery fairly early on and did something I don't usually do - read the last chapter to confirm my suspicions. I probably shouldn't have though, because knowing that I was right took away a lot of the mystery. On reflection, I think I did it because the character of Hetty is rather dull. She lacks spark and is happy to be passive nearly all the time. I like my investigating heroines to be stronger, willing to buck a trend and ruffle a few feathers. I felt that Hetty just sailed through the whole thing without causing a ripple. I tended to skim few chapters a little bit more as I found the historical timeline of Beatrice and Theo much more engaging.  I always slowed down for the beautiful descriptions of the Hebrides - this is where Sarah Maine's writing truly excels, in the sense of atmosphere and putting the reader in no doubt about how moody and a little bit creepy the whole place is. The descriptions of Muirlan House were incredibly evocative, and I had shivers down my spine as Hetty entered the shell of the decrepit house for the first time.  While I liked this book, I felt that the parts involving Hetty were slow at times. However, it's a sound debut book and I'd be interested to see what Sarah Maine writes in the future.  Thank you to Allen & Unwin for the copy. My review is honest.  http://samstillreading.wordpress.com

title: The White City (The Clockwork Dark #3)
name: John Claude Bemis
review_text: This is the only book in the series with an actual year: 1893, and location: the Chicago World's Fair.  The plot is nearly overwhelmed by the weighty influence of Rowling's: \Deathly Hallows.\"  I was disappointed that Bemis did not address the assassination of President Garfield."

title: The Firebird (Slains, #2)
name: Susanna Kearsley
review_text: I rarely quit a book, but I abandoned this story in chapter 4..... Main characters who are psychics are not my cup of tea.

title: The Girl on the Train
name: Paula Hawkins
review_text: This novel was so compelling, I fell into it and remained totally absorbed in it. It is a classic thriller, but is original in its structure. The protagonist is the detective with a twist - she is a black-out drunk and so this leaves the reader with as many blanks as she has, and this was such a clever way to create suspense. The characters were fabulous and I loved that the three female characters were created without being cliched and stereotyped - each was strong, believable, relateable and individual. That is, until the end, which was rushed and seemed to mix all of the women in together, which I found disappointing. The ending isn't terrible, it is simply the lower point in a fantastic read. Highly recommend this one, not to be missed.

title: A Theft: My Con Man
name: Hanif Kureishi
review_text: Never read anything by Kureishi, this is the first time I \meet\" him and I'm impressed by how he managed to turn a personal disaster (being swindled by a half dishonest
language: half mentally troubled consultant) into a compelling novelette. He might have worked on it a bit more carefully
n_votes: maybe turned it into a full-size novel
date_added: but what he's achieved in this short text is nonetheless something you can't stop reading once you've started. Impressive."

title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (Millennium, #3)
name: Stieg Larsson
review_text: While I gave both the first and last book of the Millennium series 4 stars, and gave 5 to the second book, overall I would rate the Millennium series as 5 star. This was intense, captivating reading, beautifully drawn characters that remained true to who they were throughout all three books, and a fascinating, complicated plot.  I borrowed this series from a friend - - it is one of the few series that I plan on purchasing to keep in my library, even though I've read it.

title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Harry Potter, #7)
name: J.K. Rowling
review_text: A great end to a singular series. Rowling is a genius.

title: The Way We Fall (Fallen World, #1)
name: Megan Crewe
review_text: The ending though... it concluded but didn't wrap everything up.  I enjoyed this book though, the setting in Canada was a nice change - although the exact location was never mentioned. It reminded me a lot of Blindnesswith a more modern perspective.

title: God Emperor of Dune (Dune Chronicles #4)
name: Frank Herbert
review_text: The greatest science fiction book of all time. Rereading it as an adult has opened new dimensions on this work, and it left me awestruck a second time. The best book in the series, but the three leading up to it are essential.

title: Take Me (The Untouchables, #1)
name: T.A. Grey
review_text: Main characters were sketchy at best, little or no action, inexplicable reactions. the only thoroughly described scenes were those of...almost sex, but that's not enough in a book

title: Cress (The Lunar Chronicles, #3)
name: Marissa Meyer
review_text: Easily the best book in the series so far, Cress grabs you from the first page. The story of cyborg Cinder and Scarlet is only enhanced by Cress (Rapunzel, obviously), a lonely, brilliant, imaginative girl trapped for years on a satellite. The crew gets separated, and Cress is thrown in with Captain Thorne in the Sahara Desert. And if I loved Thorne in Scarlet, he only becomes better in Cress. OMG! My new fictional crush. He's Finnick O'Dair, Han Solo, and Dean Winchester rolled into one. There are also some truly heartbreaking moments toward the end. The storytelling is excellent, and it is nicely set up for the conclusion in Winter. Looking forward to it.

title: Cress (The Lunar Chronicles, #3)
name: Marissa Meyer
review_text: Cress, this book is action packaged. They are literally going all over the world in this book. Cress is Rapunzel, we got to meet her briefly in Cinder and I was waiting for them to communicate with each other again. So I was glad we got to learn more about her. Cause Cress is badass! This book was lovely, very insightful and the war had really begun. In this book, they had to train and recruit help, find the cure for the sickness that was plaguing humans and try to sabotage Queen Levana's plan. I love this book. I mean it was gloomy, cause a lot of separation occurred in this book and it was the start of the acquiring of life altering battle scars. I love how much Iko is included in this book and the next book, I know I've not spoken about Iko yet, but I will.  Read full review on The Book Heathen

title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Harry Potter, #7)
name: J.K. Rowling
review_text: HEART BREAKER.

title: Captain Marvel, Volume 1: In Pursuit of Flight
name: Kelly Sue DeConnick
review_text: Four stars for story, but I'm not thrilled with the art. Carol Danvers, the former Ms. Marvel steps up to take the name of Captain Marvel (going into why that's significant would take too much space) and gets pulled into a time-space adventure involving a team of female WW II adventurers, a veteran woman pilot and Carol's own origin. A very good kickoff, though I do wonder why the WW II characters seem so oblivious to the existence of super-heroes (you'd think Carol was unique, but there were a lot of them around back then).

title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (Millennium, #3)
name: Stieg Larsson
review_text: You can easily see why this series is a phenomenon. It hs an unforgettable lead character, and carefully crafted suspense throughout. This one, however, did seem to bog down among the countless minor characters, all of whom had similar Swedish names. It was a bit of a chore to keep them all straight.

title: The Iron Daughter (The Iron Fey, #2)
name: Julie Kagawa
review_text: This one was actually closer to a 3.5 for me; I enjoyed it more than the first entry in the series for sure. It still was somewhat predictable, but I was more drawn in to the story and enjoyed some of the new side characters.

title: God's Debris: A Thought Experiment
name: Scott Adams
review_text: A delivery guy walks into a room with a fire-place and an old man...they philosophize about religion and existence. Sounds like my typical day. But in this case: one claims to actually know MORE than any human should.  The author is scott adams (who wrote the Dilbert comics apparently). It seems Scotty is a creative amateur philosopher - Does anybody really ever get to be a professional philosopher? Teaching doesn't count of course (those that can't do - often teach... Ouch!). Does publishing a story book count in the upper hierarchy of deep thinkers? Sure, why not!  Fun story. I dare you to find the flaws in it? I found many. (I don't think Scott minds - he seems to have a healthy sense of humor).  Scott poorly compares all religions. He barely comprehends the deity of Christianity --- which technically destroys the value of his entire story. Some great insights, but not understanding the nature of the Trinity leaves the Debris of this God not necessary: see, God already died; remember that Jesus moment on the cross?  _________________________  The challenge with this book and every OTHER religion (outside of Christianity) is that they basically repeat what the talking snake did in the Garden of Eden:  Genesis 3  1Now the serpent was more crafty than any other beast of the field that the LORD God had made.  He said to the woman, \Did God actually say
language: 'You shall not eat of any tree in the garden'?\" 2And the woman said to the serpent
n_votes: \"We may eat of the fruit of the trees in the garden
review_len_words: 'You shall not eat of the fruit of the tree that is in the midst of the garden
column14: lest you die.'\" 4But the serpent said to the woman
column15: \"You will not surely die. 5For God knows that when you eat of it your eyes will be opened
column16: and you will be like God
column17: knowing good and evil.\"  This stories Guru claims: quote (pg. 44)  |The old man looked at nothing and said
column19: not exactly the same as being an enlightened deity knowing good and evil... but comically close. This book basically smacks of some twisty Buddhism. What doesn't nowadays? Everybody gets to be THE GOD except Jesus. People keep claiming that He never claimed to be God. (The Bible shows how He is God in every way. People just don't like it... Cause it interfere's with their divinity.) Or in the case of Islam: it interfere's with their heavenly virgin Houris concubines (kept guarded behind pavilions?) that DON'T get to be God. Any dude will give up being bits of god for that eternal lovefest.  Quote (pg. 54)  \"So
column20: you're saying God blew himself to bits - I guess that was the Big bang - and now he's piecing himself back together?\" I asked.  \"He is discovering the answer to his only question.\"  \"Does God have consciousness yet? Does he know he's reassembling himself?\"  \"He does
column21: Otherwise you could not have asked the question
column22: and I could not have answered.\"  So that's the fun we got to work with. Deepak Chopra would love this crap. Probably be in his next book. I wonder if Oprah would object to being a broken chippy bit of god?  But every theologian and philosopher (as well as scientist) should try and read this book. It will challenge them in some fun areas. Adams came up with some great stuff. This one was rather insightful:  Quote: (pg. 76) Argument about validating scientific studies  \"If they tested him with controlled experiments and he repeatedly passed
column23: I think they would conclude he had ESP.\" I said.  \"Your wrong. They would conclude that their tests were not adequately controlled and that more study needed to be done. They would say that extraordinary claims require extraordinary proof. And they would keep testing until they either got a negative result or lost interest. No skeptic would take the chance of declaring someone to have ESP if there were any risk of later being proven wrong. Their cult does not promote that sort of risk.\"  This is very applicable. Basically Secular Evolutionary science at its most naked. It simply MUST be correct...or we'd have to rethink the Biblical account and supernatural Intelligent Design... and we can't allow that in the classroom.  Why believe in a Great Flood when we can believe in 3 Ice Ages? Mock one and make endless claims about the other --- even claims that Mars was once flooded. But NEVER allow for a Global Earth flood of Biblical proportions.  So you might as well read this book - it's FUN stuff. Might cause you to question some things you easily and blindly accepted. But like most skeptics: probably NOT. Don't want to upset YOUR CULT."

title: Solo
name: Rana Dasgupta
review_text: Very good novel, separated into two parts, both with some of the same characters, but with two completely different plot lines. Endlessly fascinating and fairly unique.

title: Flora's Lot
name: Katie Fforde
review_text: 3.5 stars! I really enjoyed this book, but the whole \kissing cousins\" concept threw me off a little! The story is sweet and predictable
language: but adorable just the same. Would recommend."

title: Cress (The Lunar Chronicles, #3)
name: Marissa Meyer
review_text: AHHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!! (thats all I can manage at the moment)

title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Harry Potter, #7)
name: J.K. Rowling
review_text: ----SPOILER FREE REVIEW----  Read this in under 48 hours, and wow. I mean, wow. I really don't see how Rowling could've ended this better. I won't discuss specifics, but in The Deathly Hallows she has trumped and capped what has become a truly impressive creation. Somewhere around book five, I was struck by the realization that the Potter books had moved beyond the merely fun and into the truly good - since then, they've never dipped in quality. By far the most adult of the books, The Deathly Hallows is no exception; be prepared for brutal violence, stunning revelations from the deep past, and a thoroughly satisfying conclusion to a great series.

title: Twenties Girl
name: Sophie Kinsella
review_text: 3.5 Definitely chic-lit. Like most of Kinsella's books it rates better than average for the genre.  I might have enjoyed it more if I had read it instead of listening to the audiobook. The narrator tried to do more with accents than she was able and, as a result, I became confused and distracted.  Do check your desire for a reality-based storyline on the first page. If you can let go and just enjoy the crazy storyline, you'll have a lot of fun with this book. Very cute read with a very satisfying conclusion.

title: Cress (The Lunar Chronicles, #3)
name: Marissa Meyer
review_text: The 3rd book in what I think is a 4 book series. Fun sci-fi twist on classic fairy tales.

title: Thorn Queen (Dark Swan, #2)
name: Richelle Mead
review_text: This book was really good. I liked it a lot better than the first one and what happened in the end made me very HAPPY!!

title: The Reluctant Fundamentalist
name: Mohsin Hamid
review_text: The metaphor and symbolism in this book is astounding. It's not overly done but it's also not overly obvious either.  Additionally, there were times that I felt terrible for the narrator as well as other Pakistani immigrants and Americans post 9/11. There were also times that I felt angry toward his views of America.  So as not to spoil the book for anyone else, READ IT. It's such a great read.

title: Blankets
name: Craig Thompson
review_text: Art- ****  Plot- **  This was such a fast read, even for a graphic novel, it's 550+ pages and I read it in one morning, the art is fantastic and the stand out of this book, the plot/memoir in this coming of age semi autobiographical book not so much, trough out I kept thinking: Why is this story being told? Does this story needs to be told? What am I taking from this story?  The part about his childhood and the relationship with his brother is good, but most of the story takes part in a 2 week visit to a girl he meets at church camp, you can tell this person had a lasting impact on the rest of his life. It also highlights his struggles with christianity and the restrictive community he grew up in.  I want to read more graphic novels but this one was not for me.

title: The Seer and the Sword (Healer and Seer, #1)
name: Victoria Hanley
review_text: I still love this book. Not matter how many times I read it, I always fall in love witht he story, plot characters and the special bond Tornia and Landen have always had. I love Landen's compassionate heart and his knowledge and skills to outwit his opponets. I love Tornia's firey spirit especially when she breaks away from Vesputo's spell. When both Landen and Tornia were living in Desante, they both craved the same style of living and both thought of each other not knowing where the other was. Tornia and Landen match so well even when they had first met, the crystal just strengthened their bond. Beautiful story about the rise and fall of power from many worlds. I don't think I will ever get tired of reading it.

title: Selected Poems
name: William Carlos Williams
review_text: How to show WCW to friends:  open the book to red wheel barrow  (or your favorite of the shorter pomes)  let/make 'em read it  then shut the book quickly  soes they kin see Doc Williams  in the blossoms of the cherry tree.  ah.

title: The Tiger's Wife
name: Tea Obreht
review_text: This book has been getting lots of hype and I just don't get it. I liked parts of the book, the stories surrounding the tiger's wife and the man who couldn't die; but other parts of the story just dragged. I found myself getting distracted while reading it. I'll be anxious to see how others responded to this book.

title: The Firebird (Slains, #2)
name: Susanna Kearsley
review_text: This follow-up to The Winter Sea was a good read and if you liked The Winter Sea, you'll enjoy this. In my opinion, The Firebird isn't really a sequel and both books can be read and understood completely independent of each other, but it was nice to have the background from The Winter Sea. I really enjoyed reading Anna's story and seeing more of beloved characters from the previous book.  Susanna Kearsley has a writing style that brings you right into the story. Her books are lengthy, but they're so interesting that they don't feel as long as they are. This is only the second book I've read by her, but I'll definitely be reading more.  Like, The Winter Sea, The Firebird tells two stories - one set in the present day and one set in the past. While I especially liked the character of Robbie in the present day story, I found Anna's story from the past much more interesting and intriguing. When the author took the story out of the past and back into the present day story, I did find myself a little irritated, probably because I wasn't nearly as engaged in that story. Another thing I found myself doing while reading the present day story passages, was skipping over a lot of the description of St. Petersburg, mainly because I wanted to get back to Anna's story. For those reasons, this book gets 4 stars instead of 5. Overall a very enjoyable read.  PS: It's also very interesting to read the section at the end of the book where the author explains some of her research into the historical figures. From reading her books you can tell they are well researched, but I enjoy reading about the research as well.

title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Harry Potter, #7)
name: J.K. Rowling
review_text: Probably the MOST emotional Harry Potter book in the series...  ...I love it. *SOBS*

name: Amelia Hutchins

title: The Girl on the Train
name: Paula Hawkins
review_text: If you liked this review, please check out more on my website www.mackenziesmountain.com  The Girl on the Train by Paula Hawkins has been one of the hottest book club picks around for a couple of years now. It is a thriller written from the points of view of three complicated, troubled women: Anna, Megan, and Rachel (the main character).  I picked this book to read because it has been so popular for such a long time, and I like to keep at least sorta-up on to date on these types of books, considering that I work as a library clerk. It makes it easier to chat with customers about different types of books, and make recommendations if I am well-read in more genres that just my favourite one or two. And lately, I've just been in a bit of a book rut so it was time to read a few outside of romance / erotica!  I liked the pacing of The Girl on the Train. It is an easy read that I got through in two sittings. I felt that the outcome of the novel was hidden for most of the novel, although I did suspect the killer's identity several chapters before Rachel did.  One of things that I appreciated was the author's decision to not make any particular characters the \good guys\". Every single character from the Rachel to the police officers and the \"red-haired man in the train station\" were flawed people
date_added: to overcome. It helped the story to stay grounded in my opinion and stopped me from assuming the character's POV as my own. I didn't particularly cheer for any one or root against the other.  Overall
review_len_words: I did find this book to be entertaining but I am not sure why it received as much attention as it did. I can definitely name several books along this line that I would recommend much more strongly to another reader
column14: for one. This story was good
column15: I just didn't find it to be particularly memorable."

title: God's Debris: A Thought Experiment
name: Scott Adams
review_text: The \Avatar\" is an interesting character
language: and while the theology might not always even make sense
n_votes: but it definitely does one important thing: Makes you ask questions.  The audio performer is great too."

title: Harry Potter e a Pedra Filosofal (Harry Potter, #1)
name: J.K. Rowling
review_text: I was 14 yrs-old when I first read it, and I love it! Today, I prefer the other ones, but still, it's an amazing teen book that everybody can read, including the not so teen people ^^

title: Shogun (Asian Saga, #1)
name: James Clavell
review_text: This book is absolutely radical. I was hooked from the second early on in the book when the antagonist, a pretty badow english dude who gets shipwrecked in japan, sees a samurai lob off a peasants head with impunity. This book is looooooooooong(which is a plus for me), and very rewarding. It piqued my interest in japanese culture outside of videogames.

title: The Light in the Ruins
name: Chris Bohjalian
review_text: I really enjoyed this...and a new author for me. I'll have to see if he has more.

title: Cascade
name: Maryanne O'Hara
review_text: I first found out about this book in connection with the Women's National Book Associations table at the Boston Book Festival--Maryanne O'Hara is a fellow member. At first I was dubious whether I wanted to read it because it takes place in the 20th century, which I don't consider 'historical', and because the adultery theme usually puts me off. Then I was caught up in the story of the creation of a mid-Massachusetts water reservoir (the fictional version of the very real Quabbin Reservoir) and the creative drive of the protagonist. At the end, I could not put the book down.

title: Swann's Way (In Search of Lost Time, #1)
name: Marcel Proust
review_text: Richard Howard's introduction, delightful in itself, warns Proust that the modern reader no longer knows how to relax and enjoy a good book. How true! In doing so, I think the reader learns to appreciate Proust's masterpiece. Taking in the life work of a writer reminds one of what a novel should aspire to be (and how often one wastes in lesser works). Howard also allows the reader to skim if they must, but, above all, enjoy. With that, I offer the same: Enjoy this book. I wish I could give it more justice (how I, with Swann, fell for Odette, how I and the Narrator together read in the garden) but five more volumes await me! (Furthet review pending)

title: Revive (Storm MC, #3)
name: Nina  Levine
review_text: My mouth is hanging open, there are no words for the shock I am feeling after finishing Revive. I am not going to give anything away here but just know club business is heating up at Storm MC.  Nash, oh Nash, you are a close second for being the king of awesome dirty mouth biker. I LOVE Nash and Velvet together.

title: Turn of the Moon (Royal Shifters, #1)
name: L.P. Dover
review_text: 4.5 Stars  There is no way Bailey will allow herself to be mated to the abusive Kade and if running is the only way to escape him then that's what she will do.  But after a week of running she finds herself in the territory of another wolf one she can't seem to keep her thoughts away from. What Ryker tells her about life is so different from what she's always known, is it possible he's telling the truth? And why would her whole life have been a lie?  Bailey is one tough chick she is not one to take things lying down and will not let others control her.  Ryker is an alpha male in every way, but he's also a big sweetie. He takes care of those around him even when they don't even know he's there. You can see right away just how much he has always cared for Bailey by the way he treats her.  This story takes you into a new and exciting world with wolves and witches and you never know what else may come in time. I enjoyed seeing this world come to life through the characters and it truly felt like you were right there with them through whatever emotions they were going through at any time.  The characters were well told so you feel like you got a great understanding of them and their motives. I definitely enjoyed it and am excitedly awaiting the next one to come out!

title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Harry Potter, #7)
name: J.K. Rowling
review_text: This final volume in the Harry Potter series takes Harry, Ron and Hermione on a quest to complete Dumbledore's request that they destroy Voldemort's horcruxes and thus make him vulnerable. It is also the volume in which the secrets and lies people have told and lived by for years are exposed forcing Harry and his friends to re-evaluate their beliefs, their loyalties and grow up.  As the other volumes in the series, this book grabs the reader and doesn't let go until the last few pages. I tend to read a chapter or two at a time and found it difficult to not sneak in extra reading time by the time I was half way through.  This book must follow the others in the series as it brings together all the various threads started in the other books. Many of the characters from other books reappear. The events that occur are dependent on events in other books.  The series is good reading as enjoyment. It is also good reading for aspiring authors as it does hook readers, something all authors hope to do with their own novels.

title: Lady Luck (Colorado Mountain, #3)
name: Kristen Ashley
review_text: Gonna give this author another try. First book I read by her, At Peace, I couldn't finish....let's see how this one goes.  This author is not for me. Unlike At Peace I did manage to finish this one & that's about the only positive thing I can say.

title: Invisible Threads
name: Annie Dalton
review_text: Aww this book is sweet and touching. :) a little confusing at first. But if you liked Sarah Dessen books then I'm sure you'll like this one. :D

title: Building Social Business: The New Kind of Capitalism That Serves Humanity's Most Pressing Needs
name: Muhammad Yunus
review_text: Overly optimistic about people's value in making the world a better place, at times. Focuses less on the competitive benefits of the social enterprise and more on the technological benefits, which was disappointing to me. Also focused less on the benefit to business than pure altruism.  Overall, probably a 3.5 book, bumped to 4 because it was inspirational via examples.

title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Harry Potter, #7)
name: J.K. Rowling
review_text: I am reading this aloud to Sam before bed every night. I love our Mommy/Son reading time! :)

title: Blankets
name: Craig Thompson
review_text: Absolutely beautiful graphic novel -- the artwork was breathtaking and the story was touching and perfectly told. If you aren't sure if graphic novels are for you, this one would be a good place to start. Looking forward to more graphic novels by Thompson.

Not exactly an epic kind of love story, but great, realistic and at one point I started enjoying, its when Apurv decides to ruin everything and cheats on Radhika.. dishonesty or cheating in relationships is something Im not immune to yet,,,  I liked how Radhika treasured Apurv, would have loved if it was mutual...

title: Dreamfever (Fever, #4)
name: Karen Marie Moning

title: My Mother's Secret
name: J.L. Witterick
review_text: This was a fascinating book; it is a novelization of a true story. Set in Sokal, Poland during the German Invasion and all the Jews are being rounded up and put into the ghetto or being killed outright and anyone who helps the Jews is summarily executed for their efforts. That's what makes Franciszka and her daughter, Helena true heroes these women put their lives on the line for people they barely knew, they gave them a place to hide, food and gave them their lives because none of these people would have survived the Nazi's, well Vilheim may have survived but his soul would have become so scared by what he was forced to do that he would have never been the same.  These two amazing women not only hid 3 Jewish families but also a German Soldier who could not do what his commanding officer was asking of him he had an acquaintance with Franciszka, who reminded him of his Oma and of course she hid him , she hid them all and none knew about the others.  This woman's courage just floored me especially when she invited the German Commandant to dinner with 2 Jewish families in the basement and another in the shed but it made her above suspicion and when the Germans moved tanks into her yard and were a little close for comfort she talks them into moving everything out of her yard when asked how she did it she says, \Always point out what is in the best interest of the other person if you want them to do something. Works on everyone.\"  There are some great quotes in this book these are my favorites:  \"Helena
language: there are three kinds of people in the world. One that would have seen the suffering cat and not have given it a second thought. Another that would have seen the same cat and said to themselves
date_added: isn't that a pity' before continuing about their business. Finally
review_len_words: there is the kind that sees the suffering
column14: and then goes one step further by taking action to help. That is you. You didn't leave the cat there to perish. I am proud that you are my daughter. Think what a wonderful place the world would be if everyone was like that.\"  \"I always thought courageous people were those who were not afraid. Meeting Franciszka and her daughter
column15: I realize that courageous people are afraid like everyone else. They just act despite the fear.\"  \" If you choose to do the right thing
column16: it's a conscious decision at first. Then it becomes second nature. You don't have to think about what is right because doing the right thing becomes who you are
column17: like a reflex. Your actions with time become your character.\"  This was a great book and I would highly recommend this story
column18: it's a short book that packs a powerful punch.  4 Stars"

title: Vathek
name: William Beckford
review_text: I read this in conjunction with \Castle of Otranto\" while travelling in Japan recently.  Much like \"Otranto\"
n_votes: mostly silly storytelling exercise that does not offer a lot to the modern horror fiction reader. As I read it
date_added: I felt it was an attempt at satirizing a tale out of 1001 Arabian Nights.  I usually don't like discussing plots
review_len_words: but I think I will here because I feel I need to expand on my last point. The story starts with a wealthy Caliph who desires extreme power and arcane knowledge. He meets a black Indian who promises him all of this. The Indian rarely speaks and there is an episode where he becomes a magical fat ball that plays havoc with the whole city in which the Caliph lives as all the palace officials try and catch it and kick it. His mother
column14: has a great interest in the arcane and burns mummies and bodies and etc. with the help of one-eyed black negresses that attend on her every whim in her magical tower inside the palace. The Indian is in fact an evil genie that lures the Caliph onto a journey to his lair through a mountain in which bizarre animals eat and murder a large part of the Caliph's staff and soldiers as they travel to the genie's lair. There is an odd love triangle along the way involving the Caliph. In the end
column15: when he reaches the lair of the genie
column16: he is damned to the most painful torments based on his mother's desire for power and his own greed.  In other words -- a Gothic take on an Arabian Nights fable. An odd mix to my mind.  One is struck by the author's prodigious imagination in writing this tale
column17: but I ultimately wondered why he felt the need to write this so haphazardly -- I couldn't tell if he wanted the reader to take it as a joke or if he was serious in his moral at the end.  Read the introduction for sure -- the author's life was just as odd as this tale was."

title: The Iron Daughter (The Iron Fey, #2)
name: Julie Kagawa
review_text: Actual Rating: 3.8/5  You can find this review, together with other reviews of books I've read in my blog: http://floatinginathousandworlds.blog...  MY REVIEW:  When i first read the Iron King (The Iron Fey #1) I was mainly dissapointed by the narrative style and Meghan's dumbness. Then The Iron Daughter fell into my hands, and i wasn't expecting at all that I would fall for a book of this series. See, the narrative style got better so I only had to cope with Meghan's infinite stupidity, whining and love problems but there was a payback: Lots of action, lots of abrupt changes, lots of slaps-in-the-face that made Meghan change to someone better!  The Iron Fey has a Part 1 and Part 2. If you want to avoid getting spoiled at all, you can skip the following to the part where I review the characters.  Part 1 is Meghan's stay and captivity in Tir Na Nog where lots of interesting things happen. That's the point where she faces Queen Mab's endless cruelty and she is all alone as Ash claims that he tricked her and was not in love with her all along. Tir Na Nog is so artfully created, I was instantly enamored and filled with fear - the ice-glazed palace, the Goblin Market, the humans encased in ice that decorate the palace, the looming darkness. At some point things change, the truth is uncovered and Ashe helps Meghan escape, where they meet the fact that there is a traitor in the winter court. They find shelter in an old fort, a place where Ash and Ariella (Ash's betrothed and long dead beloved one) used to stay between their hunts. That's where Robin Goodfellow/Puck joins them and Ash decides to leave, as he has to end things between him and Meghan once and for all. Part 1 ends in a heartbreakingly beautiful scene, where in a sea of glowing magical flowers that create Ariella's dancing and happy image, it becomes clear to Meghan that Ash loved the dead girl all along. Then Ash leaves.  Part 2 is where the action begins. Puck, Meghan, Grimalkin the cat and an unexpected ally find refuge in the Exiles Queen Leanansidhe's apartments where they plan how to overthrow the new Iron King.  THE CHARACTERS:  1) Meghan Chase: Well, if you've read the rest of the review, you will probably have realized that i don't have the best opinion about her. What infuriates me most is that we spend most of the book with a Meghan like this:  Why? Because of Ash, who for all she knows, tricked her, left her, and is still in love with a dead girl. For Fuck's Sake Meghan!  2) Ash:  \He shook his head

title: Blankets
name: Craig Thompson
review_text: One of the best novels, in any genre, that I've ever read.

title: Rapture (Fallen, #4)
name: Lauren Kate
review_text: I wish I could do 3.5 instead of 3 stars.  A satisfying conclusion to the series. Overall, all of the books seemed a little drawn out, but the story and plot were romantic and captivating. I'm glad I read the series.

title: The Time Keeper
name: Mitch Albom
review_text: I'm only giving this 3 stars because the prose was so beautifully crafted as I expected from this author. I understood the message about how precious life is and how valuable our time here should be spent and never wasted. I just wasn't impressed about the way in which the story was told. If he wanted to create Father Time and people that needed realizing their value, I would have preferred deeper subject matter and more richly created characters.  Both Sarah and Victor I found were annoying and hard to connect with for me. I found Sarah, a teen girl who is so desperate for attentions from a boy that she completely ignores all the signs from him that he's not really interested. The boy she was interested in was a complete cliche by the way. As for victor? Well rarely are there people with that much money and power to be likable in the first place. He reminded me of Mr. burns from the Simpsons. I think they even had an episode about the very thing victor was doing to himself.  I waited for that big A-ha moment but was sadly disappointed when it didn't happen. All that said, I loved the narrator of this audio, he was wonderful. Together with Mitch alboms beautiful words and his rich narration is mostly where the strs came from, not the story alone.

title: Cress (The Lunar Chronicles, #3)
name: Marissa Meyer
review_text: THIS BOOK WAS AMAZING!!!

title: The Narrowboat Girl (Narrowboat Girl, #1)
name: Annie Murray
review_text: What an incredible story by Annie Murray. Yet again she has this amazing gift of making you feel as if you are there looking on. I found this story to be heart rendering the way the girls were treated by the stepfather an evil monster. The story was told with such passion she had you engrossed from the first page. I have read many of her novels and this is up there with the rest.

title: Cress (The Lunar Chronicles, #3)
name: Marissa Meyer
review_text: I just love everyone so much I'm crying

title: The Girl on the Train
name: Paula Hawkins
review_text: Wow!! I read this in a day. I could not put it down!

title: Ting Tang Tony (Has-Been #1)
name: Kat DeSalle
review_text: To be honest, I was a little hesitant to try this one because of the cover, even though I knew from a Facebook group I'm in that the authors are super cool chicks. I guess I assumed it was going for farcical erotic sex romp with that cover and title, but then you read it, and IT'S NOT THAT AT ALL! It's actually got substance and characters you dig into and emotional depth that pulls you in.  The authors offered some ARC copies and I was lucky enough to get one, and when I got into the story, I realized that all of my assumptions based on the cover were off. Yes, there's comedy in it, but that's more from the interplay of the characters--Tony's family, i.e. in the way that your group of friends become your family, and in this case, all of Tony's friends are from his time in the porn industry! And then there's Emmy, the woman Tony meets who's not a part of his world at all, and when the sparks start to fly there, you just can't stop reading. They were so REAL together, it was refreshing. Literally, I couldn't put this book down, I read it in a day, it was so good.  Because yes, while this novel is about a retired porn star (book starts with his retirement party - he's all of 38 years old), it's also asking larger questions that all of us have faced at one time or another about how to handle it when one phase of our lives end and another begins. It's wicked scary! Though granted, not all of us are driving around rented Lamborghini's  Anyway, there's a lot more sweetness in this tale than you might expect from a book about a has-been porn star, and I can't leave off this review without giving out a loud holla to all the small-junked men out there! Tony represents! No more shame!

title: The Ask and the Answer (Chaos Walking, #2)
name: Patrick Ness
review_text: A fast-paced middle chapter to this series. Unlike some trilogies, this middle book stands alone as a great entry and not just a bridge to the final chapter.

title: Wonderland Creek
name: Lynn Austin
review_text: EXCELLENT. I think this is the best book Lynn Austin has written. Very believable and suspencful..
